metadata.name: Embodied Tactile Sensing
metadata.description: Tactile and haptic perception capabilities for embodied AI systems, covering contact detection, force sensing, texture discrimination, and haptic exploration. These concepts enable interpretability of touch-based reasoning in robotic and embodied agents.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: The sensory modality through which an agent perceives physical contact, pressure, texture, and mechanical interaction with the environment

positive_examples: The robot's tactile perception detected that the object was slipping from its grasp.
Tactile perception enabled the prosthetic hand to distinguish between hard and soft objects.
The agent's tactile awareness indicated excessive contact force with the delicate surface.
Haptic perception revealed the texture gradient across the material sample.
training_hints.disambiguation: Sensory awareness of touch properties, not mere physical contact

candidates.definition: The computational process of acquiring and interpreting signals from touch sensors to understand physical contact properties

positive_examples: The tactile sensing array provides 256 pressure readings across the fingertip surface.
High-resolution tactile sensing detected the embossed Braille characters.
The robot's tactile sensing system integrates capacitive and resistive sensor modalities.
Tactile sensing revealed micro-vibrations indicating surface defects.
training_hints.disambiguation: Active computational processing of touch sensor data, not mere sensor activation

candidates.definition: Determining whether and where physical contact exists between the agent and objects or surfaces in the environment

positive_examples: Contact detection triggered when the gripper first touched the cup's surface.
The contact detection system localized the touch point to within 2mm accuracy.
Distributed contact detection identified simultaneous touches at three fingertip locations.
Contact detection distinguished between intentional grasp contact and accidental collision.
training_hints.disambiguation: Computational determination of contact existence and location, not mere collision

candidates.definition: Measuring the magnitude and distribution of forces and pressures exerted during physical contact

positive_examples: Force-pressure sensing indicated 5N of grip force distributed across the contact patch.
The pressure sensing skin mapped the load distribution during the manipulation task.
Force sensing detected the moment when the object's weight fully transferred to the gripper.
Pressure sensing revealed uneven contact suggesting the object was tilted.
training_hints.disambiguation: Quantitative measurement of contact forces, not subjective weight perception

candidates.definition: Detecting tangential forces and relative motion between the agent's surface and contacted objects, indicating potential slippage

positive_examples: Shear-slip detection sensed the incipient slip before the object fell.
The slip detection signal triggered an automatic grip force increase.
Shear sensing measured the tangential forces as the object was being pulled.
Slip detection differentiated between object motion and sensor noise.
training_hints.disambiguation: Predictive detection of slip conditions, not observation of dropped objects

candidates.definition: Distinguishing surface properties such as roughness, smoothness, patterns, and material characteristics through touch

positive_examples: Texture discrimination classified the surface as wood grain based on the spatial frequency pattern.
The robot's texture sensing distinguished between sandpaper grades through controlled stroking.
Texture discrimination identified the fabric as corduroy from its periodic ribbed pattern.
Haptic texture analysis revealed microscale surface features invisible to vision.
training_hints.disambiguation: Computational analysis of texture properties, not subjective tactile impression

candidates.definition: Detecting and analyzing vibrations transmitted through contact, including those from object interactions, motors, or environmental sources

positive_examples: Vibration sensing detected the 60Hz hum indicating the motor was running.
Tactile vibration analysis identified the tool as a running drill by its spectral signature.
Vibration sensing through the gripper detected that the held container had liquid sloshing inside.
High-frequency vibration sensing aided texture discrimination during surface exploration.
training_hints.disambiguation: Computational vibration analysis through contact, not mere awareness of shaking

candidates.definition: Active exploratory procedures using touch to gather information about object properties such as shape, weight, and material

positive_examples: Haptic exploration through contour following revealed the object's 3D shape.
The robot performed lateral motion haptic exploration to assess surface texture.
Enclosure and pressure exploratory procedures estimated the object's compliance.
Haptic exploration combined multiple procedures to build a tactile object model.
training_hints.disambiguation: Purposeful tactile information-gathering procedures, not incidental contact

candidates.definition: Assessing whether a grasp is secure and unlikely to fail under expected forces and motions

positive_examples: Grasp stability estimation predicted the current grip would fail during the planned rotation.
The tactile-based grasp quality metric indicated a stable three-finger precision grasp.
Grasp stability assessment triggered a re-grasp when the margin of safety dropped below threshold.
Real-time grasp stability estimation adjusted grip force during dynamic manipulation.
training_hints.disambiguation: Computational assessment of grasp security, not intuitive grip confidence

candidates.definition: Determining the stiffness or softness of objects and surfaces through tactile interaction

positive_examples: Surface compliance estimation determined the fruit was ripe based on its yield under gentle pressure.
The compliance sensing procedure classified the material as foam rubber.
Stiffness estimation guided appropriate grip force for the deformable object.
Compliance mapping revealed the tumor as a stiff region within soft tissue.
training_hints.disambiguation: Quantitative compliance measurement, not subjective softness impression

candidates.definition: A protective sensory signal indicating that contact forces or conditions have exceeded safe operating thresholds, analogous to nociception

positive_examples: The pain-like overload signal triggered immediate withdrawal when joint torque exceeded limits.
Tactile overload signals caused the robot to release the grip before sensor damage occurred.
The nociceptive subsystem generated a high-priority interrupt when skin pressure spiked.
Pain-like signals from the fingertip prevented further force application to the fragile component.
training_hints.disambiguation: Functionally protective sensory signal, not mere threshold violation detection
